IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
The following incident was partially recorded via my MSP issued Body Worn Axon Camera.

Incident:
Hit and Run Collision, MSP Westminster Barrack DUI #23-014

Location:
3448 Littlestown Pike
Westminster, Maryland 21158

Date/Time Reported:
January 29th, 2023 at approximately 1842 hours

Attachments:
-Intoximeter Worksheet
-DR-15, Advice of Rights
-DR-15a, Order of Suspension
-Citations Issued
-MVA Printout of Suspect
-Photocopy of Suspect's West Virginia Driver's License
-MVA Printouts of Victims
-Approved ACRS Report

Victim(s)
-Garey Lovell Barrick 3rd
DOB: 09/16/1994, W/M
3448 Littlestown Pike
Westminster, MD 21158
MD Sdx: B-620-271-550-719
443-547-1704

-Francis Edward Candeloro Jr
DOB: 02/16/1987, W/M
353 Cromwell Street
Orbisonia, PA 17243
PA Sdx: 30786256
410-960-4545

Suspect:
Richard Bradley Genco Jr
DOB: 02/19/1990, W/M
*No Fixed Address*
7796 Winchester Ave
PO Box 421
Inwood, WV 25428
WV Sdx: G155451
443-379-6440

Certifications:
-Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (A.R.I.D.E.) training course
-National Highway Safety Transportation Administration (NHSTA) certified to conduct Standardized Field Sobriety Test (SFST)
-Preliminary Breath Test (PBT) Operator
-Certified police officer in the state of Maryland with over 40 hours of training in DUI detection with live donors at the Maryland State Police Academy.

Weather:
I observed the weather to be approximately 30 degrees Fahrenheit and clear conditions were present.

Narrative:

Vehicle in Motion: (Phase One)
     On January 29th, 2023 at approximately 1842 hours, I, TFC Hollinger #6938 of the Maryland State Police Westminster Barrack, responded to the area of 3448 Littlestown Pike in Westminster, Carroll County, Maryland, for a reported hit-and-run collision. I arrived on-scene and made contact with the first victim, Francis Candeloro Jr, who was identified by his Pennsylvania driver's license. Candeloro stated a vehicle had struck his vehicle, as well as the neighbor's vehicle, and then fled the scene. Candeloro then stated his neighbor had chased after the striking vehicle because it had failed to stop at the scene of the collision. I was then advised by Master Trooper Fair #5334 that the second victim, as well as the suspect, were now at a nearby parking lot at the intersection of Littlestown Pike and Old Hanover Road. I then rendezvoused with M/T Fair at the second location, and made contact first with the second victim. The second victim was identified by his Maryland driver's license as Garey Lovell Barrick 3rd. Barrick had confirmed he followed the suspect because he had appeared to flee from the scene where the collision occurred. I then observed the suspect with his vehicle, a red Dodge Ram 1500 truck with West Virginia Registration "1WU667." The suspect was the only occupant of the vehicle. The suspect's vehicle had severe right side damage, indicative of striking the victims' vehicles on the right shoulder of the roadway where the incident occurred. 

Personal Contact: (Phase Two)
     I made contact with the driver of the suspect vehicle, who was later verified by his West Virginia driver's license as Richard Genco Jr, DOB: 02/19/1990. I asked Genco to describe the events that occurred leading up to the incident. Genco stated he was traveling southbound on Littlestown Pike and had attempted to use his cell-phone while operating the vehicle. Genco stated as a result he lost control and struck the two victim's vehicles which were located on the shoulder. While speaking to Genco, I detected the strong odor of alcoholic beverages coming from his breath and person. I asked Genco if he had consumed any alcoholic beverages prior to operating his vehicle. Genco stated he did, to which he elaborated further and stated he had one drink and a ''flight'' of beers at a brewery. I asked Genco if he would complete standardized field sobriety testing to determine if alcohol had been a contributing factor to the collision. Genco was cooperative and stated he would complete testing.

Pre-Arrest Screening: (Phase Three)
     Prior to completing Standardized Field Sobriety Testing, I asked Genco if he had any pre-existing medical conditions, or if he took medications for any ailments. Genco stated he had previous physical injuries to his lower body, but would attempt to complete the tests to his ability. Genco was originally wearing a hat, but removed it for the duration of testing. Standardized Field Sobriety Testing was completed in front of his vehicle. Genco was not wearing corrective lenses. 

Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (HGN): 6/6 Possible Clues Observed
    The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (HGN) test. A black pen held in my right hand was used as the test stimulus and held approximately 12-15 inches from Genco's eyes. Genco was instructed to keep his head still and follow the stimulus with his eyes only. The following signs of impairment were observed while Genco completed the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test:
-Lack of Smooth Pursuit: 2/2 clues observed
-Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation: 2/2 clues observed
-Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees: 2/2 clues observed
Vertical Nystagmus was not observed due to Genco not being able to follow the stimulus vertically due to claiming to be dizzy.

Walk and Turn: 3/8 Possible Clues Observed
    The next test given was the Walk and Turn test. Prior to Genco performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be performed. Genco was instructed to stand heel to toe with his arms at his sides while being instructed on how to complete the test. He was also instructed to not begin the test until told to start. I instructed him that he would walk in a straight line, touching heel to toe, a total of 9 steps. Genco was also told to keep his arms down at his sides for the duration of the test. Upon reaching the 9th step, he would take a series of small steps around to his left and then take 9 more heel to toe steps to complete the test. Genco was instructed that once he began the test to not stop walking until the test was completed. During the explanation of the test, I asked Genco if he understood the instructions, to which he answered he did. Genco took an extended period of time before starting the test, claiming the cold weather would impede his ability to do the test. The following signs of impairment were observed while Genco completed the Walk and Turn test:

Instructional Phase:
1.) Genco was unable to keep his balance in the starting position after losing his balance and ability to stand upright.

Walking Stage (1st Nine):
1.) Genco raised his arms from his sides for the duration of testing.

Turn: Completed Satisfactorily.

Walking Stage (2nd Nine):
1.) Genco raised his arms from his sides for the duration of testing.
2.) Genco did not walk heel-to-toe as explained for the duration of the 2nd series of steps.

One Leg Stand: 2/4 Possible Clues Observed
     Prior to Genco performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be performed. Genco was instructed to stand with his heels together and his hands down by his sides while the instructions were given. When he was instructed to begin, he was to raise the foot of his choice off the ground approximately six inches and keep it pointed straight as to be parallel with the ground. While the leg was raised, he was to keep his leg straight, look directly at the raised foot, and count out loud and to continue the test until instructed to stop. Genco was asked if he understood the instructions, which he stated he did. Genco was afforded multiple attempts to practice the test. Genco elected to lift his right foot. The following signs of impairment were observed while Genco completed the One Leg Stand test:

Balance and Count Stage:
-Genco put his right foot down after approximately 6 seconds.
-Genco raised his arms for balance after approximately 6 seconds.

After Genco completed the One Leg Stand test, I offered him a preliminary breath test, to which he refused.

Arrest:
Based on the following observations, I had probable cause to determine Genco was driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol:
-Genco causing a multi-vehicle collision on the highway and failing to remain at the scene.
-Odor of alcoholic beverages coming from Genco's breath and person.
-Admission of Genco consuming alcoholic beverages prior to operating the vehicle.
-Signs of impairment I observed while Genco performed Standardized Field Sobriety Testing.

     I placed Genco under arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol at approximately 1931 hours. Genco was placed in the front seat of MSP Marked Vehicle G-9 with its interior facing camera activated. I transported Genco to the Maryland State Police Westminster Barrack for processing. While in route to the Barrack, I continued to detect the odor of alcoholic beverages coming from Genco's breath and person.

I arrived at the Barrack where Genco was advised his DR-15 Advice of Rights. At 2007 hours, Genco refused to complete the intoximeter test. Genco signed the DR-15a Order of Suspension prior to departing the Barrack.

At approximately 2130 hours, Genco was released from police custody to a sober driver at the Maryland State Police Westminster Barrack. Genco was provided with the citations attached to this report, a Notice to Appear, and a Notice of Counsel.

I request this case be closed due to arrest.

All events occurred in Carroll County, Maryland.

23-MSP-003697

TRAFFIC COLLISION AND DUI.

BWC Supplement Report

Date/Time of Incident: 01/29/2023, 1848 hours

This incident was captured on Body Worn Camera assigned to M/Tpr Fair and uploaded to Axon Evidence under this case number.

Narrative:

On 01/29/2023, at approximately 1848 hours, I was on duty, operating a marked MSP patrol vehicle: G-39.   I responded to the area of 3448 Littlestown Pike, Westminster, Carroll County, MD, to assist TFC Hollinger with a traffic collision.  As I was arriving in the area, I observed several vehicles in the Lion Club Park, located on Old Hanover Rd, off of Littlestown Pike.  One of the vehicles was a red Dodge pickup, display West Virginia registration 1WU667.  This vehicle had noticeable passenger side damage (some old and rusted, some fresh) and a flat passenger side front tire.  The self-identified driver of the red Dodge pickup identified himself by name and date of birth (subsequently confirmed by MVA photo comparison) to be RICHARD BRADLEY GENCO.  I made the following observations of the driver:

-emotionally agitated: nervous, repetitive statements and movements (shaking, pacing, wringing of hands)
-blood shot eyes
-STRONG odor of alcoholic beverage on breath and person

TFC Hollinger responded to my location and I vehemently encouraged him contact and to have an in-depth conversation with GENCO.  I was able to captured the Standardized Field Sobriety Tests administered to GENCO on my BWC.  GENCO had difficulty maintaining balance, walking heel touching toe, and following instructions. 

I refer to TFC Hollinger’s report for further.

All events occurred in Carroll County, MD.

Narrative:
    On February 14th, 2023 at approximately 1330 hours, I responded to 3456 Littlestown Pike in Westminster, MD to meet with the homeowner, Jessica Granger, in reference to this incident. Granger provided video footage of the hit-and-run collision. The footage at normal speed confirms the information provided by Barrick that he had to rapidly leave his residence to follow the suspect who fled the scene of the collision. The footage was placed by Granger on a flash drive and processed at the Westminster Barrack on an MSP Form 67 Chain of Custody.

All events occurred in Carroll County, Maryland.
